channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: The Perl and Raku Conference 2025
item.description: Greenville, South Carolina, USA

item.title: German Perl/Raku Workshop Conference 2025
item.description: Munich, Germany

item.title: Boston.pm monthly meeting
item.description: Virtual event

item.title: Paris.pm monthly meeting
item.description: Paris, France

item.title: Boston.pm monthly meeting
item.description: Virtual event

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description: Great CPAN modules released last week.

item.title: Counting the XOR
item.description: Python makes me fall in love again and again. Incredibly powerful and easy to follow. Well done and keep it up.

item.title: Count Xor, ha ha ha
item.description: My personal favourite Postscript one-liner is USP of the post. Highly recommended.

item.title: Count Common from The Weekly Challenge 308
item.description: Clever use of set in Raku and Python, ended up one-liner. Keep it up great work.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge #308
item.description: Simple and straight forward approach makes it so easy to decode. Nice work, thanks for sharing.

item.title: AND and XOR
item.description: Great detailed XOR operation is very interesting, and definitely not to be missed. Thanks for the contributions.

item.title: Avoid Common Traps, and Reduce the XOR
item.description: Lots of mathematical magic shared with this week contribution. Bitwise operation is always tricky. Well done.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 308
item.description: The post reminded me of good old Truth Table, very handy to cover the test cases. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: lazyness
item.description: Welcome back with yet another quality contributions in Raku. Great work.

item.title: Common Encodings
item.description: Compact solutions in Perl and PDL. New to PDL? You must check it out.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge: Week 308
item.description: It is one post where we get Perl and Raku magic together. On top, we have detailed discussion, incredible.

item.title: Exclusive or Common
item.description: Nice bunch of one-liners in Raku. Raku Rocks!!!

item.title: TWC308
item.description: Apart from Perl magics, there is CPAN gem, Data::Show, used as well. Cool, keep it up great work.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 308
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Count Common" and "Decode XOR" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 309
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Mind Gap" and "Min Diff". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: PEVANS Core Perl 5: Grant Report for December 2024 - January 2025
Premium XS Integration, Pt 2
item.description: This is a continuation of a series of articles about how to write XS libraries that are more convenient and foolproof for the Perl users, while not blocking them from using the actual C API.

item.title: nicsell supports the German Perl Workshop
item.description: nicsell is now supporting German Perl Workshop. nicsell is a domain backorder service, also known as a dropcatcher, which allows you to bid on a large number of domains that are currently being deleted.

item.title: #708 - Perl is growing...
item.description:
Hi there,

There are many interpretations of what it means to grow? I am using the term for new features. We get lots of improvements and new features with every release of Perl. In v5.38, the experimental class feature was rolled out in core. In the next maintenance release of Perl v5.40, new field attribute :reader was added and many other improvements. The next thing, we all waited was for field attribute :writer. Luckily it is already part of development release v5.41.7. I made this gist demonstrating the core changes.

If you are new to Perl Release Policy then there are two types of release i.e. Maintenance and Development. The even numbers are reserved for the maintenance release e.g. v5.38, v5.40 whereas odd numbers are for the development release e.g. v5.39, v5.41. The maintenance release are mostly production ready.

If you are interested in release history then please checkout the version history page. I found an interesting proposal with regard to the version number.

Recently, I got to try the different facets of parallel and concurrent programming. Please find below the list covered so far.

  1. Thread Lifecycle

  2. Multi-threading

  3. Multi-processing

  4. Thread Synchronization

  5. Process Synchronization

  6. Read/Write Lock

  7. Re-entrant Lock

  8. Livelock

  9. CPU bound Thread Performance

  10. IO bound Thread Performance

Enjoy rest of the newsletter.
